TaxonIdentification.variety_authority: S. Stokes ex M. E. Jones

treatment.description: Plants mostly erect, 1–3.5 × 1–5 dm. Aerial flowering stems erect or nearly so, scapelike or dichotomous, (0.7–)1–2.5 dm, tomentose to floccose. Leaves: blade linear to narrowly oblanceolate, (1.5–)3–9(–12) × 0.1–0.5(–0.7) cm, tomentose abaxially, less so and grayish or occasionally greenish adaxially, margins plane or more often revolute. Inflorescences umbellate or cymose divided 1–3 times and 2–5(–8) cm, or capitate and 1–2 cm; branches tomentose to floccose. Involucres 1 per node or more commonly 3–7 per cluster, turbinate to turbinate-campanulate, (2–)2.5–4 × 1.5–3 mm, usually tomentose, occasionally thinly floccose or glabrous. Flowers (2–)3–3.5(–4) mm; perianth yellow or ochroleucous, glabrous.
treatment.habitat: juniper, oak and montane conifer woodlands
treatment.discussion: Variety laxifolium is found in Idaho (Bear River County) and in Utah (Carbon, Duchesne, Emery, Juab, Millard, Salt Lake, Sanpete, Sevier, Tooele, Uintah, Utah, Wasatch, and Weber counties), where it occurs mainly on the western foothills of the Wasatch Range. Plants often have a reddish tomentum rather than the grayish tomentum of the consistently capitate expressions of vars. bannockense, nanum, and caelitum. Plants from the Tavaputs Plateau with exceedingly long, narrow leaf blades have been segregated as var. huberi, but plants with even longer leaves occur elsewhere (as in the Soldier Summit area of Utah County, Utah), and the difference is not taxonomically significant.
